well interestingly the president was

see the timeline that he defined was the

I wonder how much you think that is
affected by first of all the president's

about taxes was like talking to the
Taliban David Brooks our colleague in

to find their strategy so on the other

with you know
no fun it could be that the president
saw that you know had his tough press

that maybe they can make some more
progress this week it sounds as if at
least at the explicit level they've
tried to keep some maneuvering room
right and and that's in some ways what's
maddening to the American public about

some level it's all about the finesse
how they can get to where they want to
go despite the promises that seem on the

clearly the Republicans are looking for
a way to kind of reach some sort of
accommodation that doesn't end in
calamity one of the things that's
interesting to me is whether or not the
leaders of the Republican Party really
can lead their caucus I've had some
indications from the White House that
they think there was more ability on the
part of John Boehner and Mitch McConnell
to get their members to where they need
to go then has been led on by the talk
about the Republican caucus being out of
control what's your sense of that the
question is how much are they in control
of what happens in the Republican House
and how much is John Boehner in control
I think the White House would like to
believe that if it's John Boehner who is
ultimately in control and can get that
group of his members to kind of go along
with whatever he negotiates that's
better for the White House because I
think they feel like the two of them in
a room can actually reach some sort of
accommodation if it's not him if the
caucus is driving what John Boehner has
to do it makes everything more difficult
a Democrats have one big advantage in

op-ed columnist Ross Douthat on the
Republican strategy as they enter final
negotiations I think what we're seeing
is a replay in many ways of the way
negotiations played out over to the
government shutdown earlier this year
both sides but especially the Republican
leadership sees a strong incentive in
letting the negotiations go down to the
wire it's the best way they have to
assuage their base I think that there
are clearly Republicans in the House
were simply irreconcilable and who see
their incentives as being better to lose
valuable I don't think that that
describes the entirety of the House
Republican caucus and I think you have
three tactical things going on right you
have won the Republican sense that
they're in a relatively strong position
at the moment so you have a Republican
leadership that's willing to sort of
push the envelope and frankly as so far
every time they push the envelope the
White House has come back with
concessions which gives them a reason to
push further still there's the tactical
element of House Republicans worried
about primary challenges in the future
and finally you have the sort of bigger
picture if Barack Obama is re-elected
all of the Bush tax cuts are scheduled
to expire and you can imagine a scenario
where just by sort of doing nothing an
accepting gridlock the White House
allows those tax cuts to expire and you
have a massive net tax increase so
against that backdrop I think
Republicans have a strong again tactical
incentive to get the most they can right
now since they don't know what they'll
be able to get if Obama is re-elected
